description: From Middle English wo, wei, wa, from Old English wā, wǣ, from Proto-West Germanic *wai, from Proto-Germanic *wai (interjection), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wáy (interjection).

See also Dutch wee, German Weh, weh, Danish ve, Yiddish וויי‎ (vey); also Latin vae, Albanian vaj, French ouais, Ancient Greek οὐαί (ouaí), Persian وای‎ (vây) (Turkish vay, a Persian borrowing), and Armenian վայ (vay).

adjectives.description: woe (comparative more woe, superlative most woe)

examples: hys clerk was wo to do þat dede

entries.meaning: Great sadness or distress; a misfortune causing such sadness.
